facts.text: Appellant convicted under Section 60(a) of the U.P. Excise Act and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1000/-, and, in default of payment of the fine, to undergo imprisonment for a further period of two months.
Conviction and sentence confirmed by the Sessions Judge as well as by the High Court of Allahabad.

On 27-10-1967, at about 6.45 p.m., appellant found by raiding Excise staff in a room of a bungalow in Meerut apparently preparing something with the aid of materials found there which were seized: Five drums, each containing about 20 liters liquor of O.P. strength, the sample whereof was taken in five bottles from each tin. Three empty drums of five gallons capacity. Thirty empty bottles bearing labels. Labels, 120 in number, bearing the words Khodys Hercules. Different types of capsules, 142 in number.

Search of bungalow No. 243, Circular Road, Meerut Cantonment, taken after issue of regular search warrant Ex. Ka.1 under Section 52 of the U.P. Excise Act, 1910, by a First Class Magistrate on 26-10-1967.
Very detailed recovery Memo Exhibit Ka.2 dated 27-10-1967 signed by as many as six witnesses, in addition to having been signed by the officer who conducted the search and by the appellant himself.

Test report of the liquor in recovery memo: Contents of all the five drums of dirty white colour like characteristics smell. Hydrometer test: Drum No.1-77 F x 13.2-50.9 O.P.; Drum No.2-77 F x 13.4-50.7 O.P.; Drum No.3-76 F x 13.8-50.6 O.P.; Drum No.4-76 F x 14.2-50.2 O.P.; Drum No.5-77 F x 13.6-50.5 O.P. Hence contents of each drum are liquor of O.P. strength.

Appellant's plea: Had no concern with the bungalow; not present at the time when its search was taken; Excise Inspector came to liquor shop of Gyan Chand Chander Mohan in Sadar Bazar, Meerut, where he was working as salesman; demanded register, abused and implicated falsely.
Appellant professed ignorance about the nature of the liquid recovered from the room of the house in which he was found.
Appellant employee in a liquor shop.
In Trial Court, appellant examined witnesses to substantiate plea that he was not present at the house but taken from the shop in Sadar Bazar.
Main question in Trial Court and before Sessions Judge: Whether appellant arrested from shop in Sadar Bazar or from Kothi at Circular Road, Meerut Cantt.

Excise Inspector C.D. Misra, P.W.1, senior man incharge of raids and detection; put in 21 years service as Excise Inspector; tested lacs of samples of liquor and illicit liquor; used litmus paper, hydrometer, thermometer, smelling test.

legal_issues.text: Whether the smelling test employed by the Excise Inspector together with other circumstances were enough to justify the conclusion that the liquid recovered was illicit liquor of O.P strength?
Whether the Excise Inspector could be considered an expert whose opinion about the nature of the liquid found was opinion evidence admissible under Section 45 of the Evidence Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Liquid recovered had not been proved to be illicit liquor even if recovery from possession of appellant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Madiga Boosenna Ors., 1967 3 S.C.R. 871

petitioner_arguments.text: Need chemical or Ido-form test to determine composition; Sykes or Hydrometer test could not help in determining whether liquid contained alcohol.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State v. Madhukar Gopinath Lalge, I.L.R. 1965 Bombay 257

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence based on chemical analysis essential to establish substance was Ganja.

respondent_arguments.text: Excise Inspector had required technical knowledge and training; tested contents with litmus paper, hydrometer, thermometer, not confined to smelling.
Sufficient surrounding circumstances to buttress opinion evidence of Excise Inspector; Excise Inspectors undergo rigorous training including distillation process.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Excise Manuals and U.P. Government rules

court_reasoning.text: False defence that appellant not present indicates awareness of incriminating nature; as liquor shop employee, could not be ignorant; did not raise question in Trial Court that liquid not liquor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant wanted to keep distance from recoveries as aware of incriminating nature.

court_reasoning.text: No reason why accused could not raise question in Trial Court; prosecution could cure weakness; difficult to adopt conclusive test later.
Excise Inspector's competence not questioned in cross-examination or defence evidence; no suggestion liquid anything else.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty of defence to rebut prosecution evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Excise Inspector with 21 years service, tested lacs of samples, treated as expert under Sec 45 Evidence Act; used smelling + other tests; objects recovered proclaim nature of activity.
Boosennas case confined to its facts; not desirable inflexible rule; totality of facts satisfactorily establish liquor of prohibited strength.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court of fact decides on totality.

holdings.text: Smelling test + hydrometer + circumstances sufficient to establish illicit liquor of O.P. strength; no need for inflexible scientific rule, totality of facts decides.
Excise Inspector C.D. Misra is expert under Section 45 Evidence Act given experience and unchallenged competence.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Madiga Boosenna Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Confined to its own facts; better scientific proof desirable but not inflexible rule.
Hydrometer sufficient for strength if alcohol presence known; chemical test needed otherwise.
Chemical analysis essential for Ganja; cited Boosennas.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Opinion of Excise Inspector as expert evidence.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction and sentence under Section 60(a) U.P. Excise Act affirmed. Appellant directed to surrender to bail and serve out the sentence.

key_quotes.text: It is really for the Court of fact to decide whether upon a consideration of the totality of the facts in a case, it has been satisfactorily established that the objects recovered from the possession of the accused included liquor of prohibited strength.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on proof of liquor without inflexible scientific test.

key_quotes.text: Merely trusting to the smelling sense of the prohibition officers, and basing a conviction, on an opinion expressed by those officers, under the circumstances, cannot justify the conviction of the respondents.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Boosennas case, distinguished here due to additional tests and circumstances.

key_quotes.text: The objects recovered from the possession of the appellant almost proclaim the nature of his activity and of the liquid which could be in his possession.
key_quotes.speaker: court
